number of helpful: 4 of 12 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												Also known as Political Simulator 2013.Divinity: Dragon Commander places you in the role of well, as the name applies, a Dragon Commander in charge of an army (duh)!The game is divided into several parts, much like the Strategy games of today. The first phase involves you walking around your command ship, talking to various politicians, your generals and the adorable little imp to research upgrades for your army. After talking to them, you head on the battle phase of the game. This is where you're thrown into a map for you to manage your armies, which country builds what unit or structure, the movement of your armies and the activation of player cards (which gives you a slight advantage in combat).Combat is much like Star Wars: Empire at War -- You start off with a bunch of units, keep sending them to their deaths to try to achieve victory and call in more reinforcements when needed. Reinforcements are based on the amount of population you have in that particular area where the fighting is. Your fight is over the sea? Too bad, you'll have to make do with your current fleet and can expect no reinforcements for that fight.  The most interesting part about this is that you can morph into a Dragon as and when you want to join the battle, throwing fireballs down at people, healing your own armies or just to fly around being silly. You might find it overpowered in the first few levels. However, do expect to get shot down within a few seconds by a barrage of missiles should you try and charge the enemy army head on in dragon form later on in the levels.Of course, you can opt for the lazy option of clicking "auto-resolve" battle. The outcome of the battle is determined by the amount of troops you have and the general leading them. Quite more than often, I find myself clicking on that button just because I want to know more about the story than actual fighting. Besides fighting, you can settle down with some tea and biscuits with the various politicans, arguing over petty things like nudity being banned. I mean, who the heck cares when there's a flippin' war going on? Nope. Politicans will be politicians and thus will keep pestering you for your decisions. Your decisions WILL have an impact on the combat of the game, be it increased gold or having a certain race support you when fighting in their land. What I'll remember about this game would definately be the character voice acting. Quite often, I find myself listening to the long essays that several characters have to say. Music isn't half bad either--catchy, upbeat and pretty fun to listen to when you're commanding armies in the heat of battle.   Dragon Commander shines in it's aspect of story-telling and character developement. However, if you're looking for a solid RTS fight--this isn't the game for you. Overall however, Divinity: Dragon Commander is definately worth the pick up for it's price. And hey! It's on sale as I write this. So yes, it's definately worth the money.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												Massively annoying game.On the strategic level, the enemy starts off in control of all territories and, despite the story of many conflicting siblings, as a unified oponent.  Enemy has the resources to throw overwhelming numbers of troops into the fight each turn right from the start of the game.On the tactical level, when manually managing a fight, the enemy is almost perfectly efficient.  The AI is able to direct many groups of units simultaneously to accomplish different objectives, while at the same time managing troop construction and resources across the map.  The player, on the other hand, can only be in one place at a time, doing one thing at a time, and attempting to keep up with the AI in terms of capturing buildings and resources is impossible, by the time you have selected a unit, moved the camera across the map to the first thing you want to capture, moved the camera back and selected another unit, the enemy has placed troops on three sites.The only possible way to win a battle at any level is to steamroll the AI with vast numbers and/or overwhelmingly superior units.  Unfortunately, the AI starts off the game better equipped to do this than the player.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Divinity: Dragon Commander is an RTS/RPG hybrid game developed by Larian studios, the fellows who created Divine Divinity and Divinity II: The Dragon Knight Saga before going on to create the well received Divinity: Original Sin.At heart, Dragon Commander is an RTS game - you gather resources, make buildings, build units, and go roll over your enemy's stuff.The game may appear simple, but Larian studios decided to add a lot of risky mechanics to spice up their game. This RTS throws in a twist, one loyal to the game's name: playing as the Dragon Commander, you have the ability to drop onto the battle field personally, flying around the battle field in third person and raining down fire on your opponents. This is possibly one of the only RTS games where you have the ability to summon a super unit you control so directly.The execution of the Dragon Commander mechanic is mixed. It's an unfathomably cool idea, and having access to the dragon makes for a very fun 'super' button to push. On the other hand, actually commanding your army is more difficult in this stage - making army selections can't be done with the mouse anymore and casting unit spells becomes a bit of a headache, never mind selecting buildings and creating units out of them. Another side effect is, since the Dragon is partially controlled by the WASD keys, units will not have spells or fuctions bound to those 4 keys, making it less comfortable for those RTS players who like playing with a 'grid' setup (where abilities are hotkeyed according to where they are on the menu).As a pure RTS, the game is weak. The maps do not have wide varieties of objectives, the units are awkward to control, and the mini-map doesn't do much to help navigate. All units supposedly have strengths over others, but there are some which are clearly universaly better than others. One bonus though: free camera control, including the ability to zoom, turn, and even look upwards, a rarity in RTS games!However, despite the RTS portion of the game being weak, there is an added element which adds depth when playing the story mode: the RPG/political side of the game. Earning favor with races means that any time you hold an RTS battle in a country primarily populated with that race you will have a higher maximum army count, as well as more production from that country when you win. It is very possible that if you fail to ever compromise with a race's demands you will enter fights with a max army size a fraction of your opponent's, upon which your only hope of winning the fight is to rush them. The fact that the roleplay element of the game affects the gameplay element is a very tasteful touch which helps put importance to the political debacles presented.Sure, the politics side of the game is not executed in the best way possible and some of the decisions you are presented are obviously better than others, but it's still interesting. You are often presented with decisions such as whether you want to install a public healthcare system, tax the church system, add regulations to limit freedom of the press, etc. Most of the decisions are very tongue-in-cheek versions of current real life issues, and the choices made affect resources and gameplay. Interestingly enough, most of the more 'good' choices end up making the game harder, so compromising with the councillors you do not like is sometimes a necessity in order to have reasonable approval ratings in regions where fights are likely to occur. There are dozens upon dozens of choices to make, decisions branch out into relevant new choices, the characters have a wide variety of personalities, the voice acting is believable, and there is an enormous amount of dialogue that will simply not be seen in a single playthrough. This is all completely optional: everything can be skipped, clicked through, or ignored to get back to the RTS portion, though I wish more games had these kinds of options.All in all, the game is a bit of a power fantasy - except unlike games which turn you into a super-powered being who can screw the lives of evey person in sight (GTA, AC, TES, etc), you get the added perk of being able to screw with the lives of every person out of sight too, and they can't do a thing about it because you're the Dragon Commander/Emperor with incendiary respiration. However, despite having so many glitches and design flaws, and despite the game's concept precluding it from being taken seriously by RTS enthusiasts, at the end of the day the game is just fun. It does a lot of things that no other game of its kind has tried, and though it has not done it in the best way possible, it's the kind of game that makes one hope for a more polished and refined second attempt. As a serious game it has failed, but as a fun romp it has succeeded.I mean come on, Dragon on the battle field. For all the game's flaws, it's hard to say no to that.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												This game is very much a game of two sides. Unfortunutely, one side is pretty awful. The game is divided into the story driven, non combat based and relationship building aspect; and then the RTS combat and risk map like world view. I have to say, I honestly really like the non combat stuff. The characters are fun, they are a poke at the stereotypes of today whilst offering a little bit of comedic social commentry. The characters are great, the dilemas you get are great and they even have a point to them, as each desicsion you make has consequences for resource aquirement, combat and other things.Where it falls flat on its face is the RTS combat. By christ it sucks. Its entire concept is basically built around zerg rushing and turtling your forces. very little stratigic combat involved here. Yeah, being a dragon is kinda a cool twist but it takes away from being an RTS and it turns it into a click fest action game. Tries to do too much, whilst also doing almost nothing. Saddening really. On the plus side, once you get your generals you can shelve off battles to them. Though, you can only use any general once per turn, as in once you use a general on any battle that turn you may use no other generals. Why? I dont understand.All in all, I would only recommend it to players who can really get immersed into the non combat stuff. If you are looking for an incredible RTS experience, you will not find it here. However, personally I think the non combat aspects outway the combat.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 7, 2013
												What a strange game. It's a mishmash of Civilization, of Starcraft, of Brutal Legend, of half a dozen other things, all stripped down and neatly tied together with some excellent voice acting and beautiful visuals. No single element would hold up under heavy scrutiny, but the volume of options, modes, mechanics and meaningful choices add up to a fun time. If you think Civ was too involved or moved too slowly, if you thought Starcraft was too complicated and relied too much on twitch, if you thought Brutal Legend was a cool game but didn't like the aesthetic, and if you ever wanted to strap a jetpack to a dragon and decide whether to implement national healthcare in the same game, then it's probably the game for you, even if it might wear thin eventually from lack of depth. Even so, there's always the chance the developers will add on more content to it, like maybe some more tutorial information (not that it's too hard to figure out.) 4/5 for now, I'll update when I have some more experience.

												Really nice game, and so many sides to it, with much very polished and though it does not completely out do itself and is not completely original on most sides,though (as many reviewers will say) the ship sides politics/story is quite interesting and takes it a step further than many other games I played.... even after turn 45 when the main interest of the story slows down, you may still participate in that , which is pretty good.  Though I will add for some players, particularly players who have no interst in listenting to antoher politcal romp on play through 2 will probably find it taxing having to spend most of their turns repeating this process, though i think you can ignore them, most of the time, though I would charge myself with not allowing the dwarven idiot become prime minister ... reminds me of the UK some what...I dont know much about the dragon. I avoided it as my Gfx card sux and this game CTD(crashes to desktop) often when I zoom out and there doesn't seem to be a fix(I did look, but found nothing). The dragon doesn't seem OP, when I did use it once, infact it kept dying so this is not some silly RotR  action game where ur character kills everyone on its own*scof*.  However, the dragon does seem to have a lot of customisaton(as much research as there is for battlefield units)... shame you cant  get it as an AI controlled unit... I think the dragon is the reason why the support units are too powerful, they are a counter to  it...  Apparently you can play people online with this, which will make for interesting pvp as cpu never uses dragon (as far as i can see).The battle ground units, out side of support are pretty good i guess... there are soOO many abilites and all 95% need researching from the start, many of the units cannot be used easily against many other types, and though it does still smell of C&C's rifle men, rocketmen, buggy,tank .. hierarchy, it is both different and not quite the same... Riflemen in this instance are extremely powerful units and are not worth discarding... This is a very good thing, so given all i did was win via RTS battles, I thought RTS on this was good and yes, its more interesting than some of the newer C&C titles  haha!Hmm, some of the music is quite trippy, it can be nice; there is a wide variety of music in this, some of it not something I would call great, but some is good... All other sounds, are great, and many of the political scenes are  vocally acted and well done.... It adds to the fact that the script is actually well written I thought, the story is quite entertaining... Though it is far from perfect in every side of the polygon that it covers, some of these thigns include a really bad bias towards support units in rts mode and ( as mentioned; they can be invincible... really bad balance!)  and the game has definetly got some nasty bugs in there, one as mentioned above with my my poor gfx set up.  Antoher is evident when you force a large battle(i.e. attacking a Captial).. The engine just cant cope and kind of punishes you as it crashes your abilty to create units ( all you see are unit build bars that trail off the screen :P) whilst your opponent seems to churn them units out un waveringly, like a groupee clic's verbal diahorria.Will rewrite this later

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												The game starts you off with a turn-based war game where you push units around on a board to declare their movements, and buy new units and buildings with your gold. When your units end their turn in the same region as enemy troops, the game switches to a real-time mode where you fly around shooting fireballs while little soldiers run around on the field below you. But for some reason, now you can also build troops and buildings! But instead of using gold, you have a different resource called 'recruits' which you build up by capturing buildings called 'Recruitment Centers'. And it seems like the amount of troops you build during the engagement is much larger than the amounts you started with by pushing pieces around on the board. And now I have to keep popping out of the dragon to create new units and order them to do something useful. Extremely stressful and not interesting. These guys should have kept unit creation only in the turn-based game (so that the units you start a fight with are all you get) and let the player have fun with maybe an extremely simple set of commands to give orders in combat.TL;DR: Blowing things up as a dragon is fun. Being responsible for base construction, resource management, and troop movement at the same time is not.

												This game is the epitome of mixing RPG-style choices with Campaign board strategy AND traditional strategy gameplay. The choices that you make in the RPG sections, the upgrades you go with, the land that you take, everything factors into how the game will play out. Will you be a misogynyst and say that women don't get paid the same as men, thus being richer BUT at the same time losing morale, or have equal pay, increasing morale but lowering your money amount? This game is fun, and the RPG decisions are variations of real world issues that are hot-button topics, watching the scenes play out is fun.The game is a good value at $20.00 as well because it is definitely worth multiple playthroughs, not only for the decisions you have to make, but there are 5 different queens to choose from!Check it out, you wont regret it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												Have you ever mixed  bunch of sodas together in an attempt to make something unique and good tasting? For strategy games thats what Divinty: Dragon Commander is. It's quite ambitious in how it brings together concepts that you've probably seen in other games, separately. It takes some of Risk, some Starcraft 2, some Mass Effect and adds a jetpack wearing dragon to the mix to make a memorable gem that balances out serious and comedic moments as you go from blasting enemies on the battlefield to discussing whether or to legalize a certain plant for medical purposes, this and many other political issues in the game are downright parodies of the issues in present day politics, almost making the game an unintentional period piece of our current day and age. The RTS portion can be a little lackluster, but the ability to jump in in the form of a jetpack wearing dragon to fight alongside our forces to tip the scales makes it cooler, and for those who dont want to deal with that and enjoy the admittedly more fun empire running segments it can be auto resolved in a manner similar to the Total War series, with your chances of victory being boosted by paying your general and your various cards. At the end of the day it is a jack of all trades, master of none but the gestalt ends up being greater than the sum of the parts making th experience memorable and makes you want to play the campaign again and again to see how differently things can go and to interact with the very amusing characters in the empire running segments. For strategy fans its worth a buy, for those new to the genre it would be a good gateway to some of the bigger franchises.

Posted: June 13, 2014
												This is one of the few games that takes several generic formulas of RTS, SIM, Turn Based and air combat and mixes them all Togethor like a molotov cocktail is proud of it. Word Of Warning though, CHeck your computer to see if it can handle it...My first try with it was lagging so badly and poorly that It left a bad aftertaste for a little while. Combat with AI is generic (as do the units in terms of looks) and isn't changing much. Plus, It does have a Massive Learning Curve in terms using your unit's special abilities as well as your own. This with a very poor (in my mind) A.I. makes it okay...had it been simplified with the abilities and the enemy smarter...I would difinately try to get every one of my freind's who like RTS's.The Things that make this game (for me anyway atleast) work is both the dragon combat and your time spent on your hanger as a kingWhenever I was dragon, I felt like a badass taking down Dozens of enemys with fire (though I would reccomend a small tutorial or even a clip on how it works or just practice. I would not mind seeing a variation of something like that as a game. Meanwhile, as a king, you lead your people (undead, Elves, Dwarves, Lizard folk, Imps and humans) to victory as well as interacting with your generals and your advisors  and your queen (who you can choose) on modern political issues (Euthanasia, Enviromentalism, Freedom of speech..ETC.) Along with upgrading your forces and yourself with spells and mechcanical upgrades for your war machince. Being king makes you feel the burden of what you do and have an effect on the world around you as they are effected (equal pay means you lose more money while gaining more motivation, becomming a republic means people like you but face harder challanges.)I Love this game and had an absoulute ball. thier are many different twists and turns that are involved that I can't not reccomend  even with it's faults. If you like the idea of being a king and a Flying dragon badass...This is for you.Hail To The King Baby!

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Unusual mix of RPG (dialogues, decisions and personal stories of your crew aboard your ship, The Raven), TBS (Risk-like map, along with simplified building and research system, armies moving and such), RTS (real-time battles for provinces your invade in previous phase) and action game (when you turn into dragon during RTS battle).Each part is rather simplified and unable to carry the game on its own - yet it is combination of all those modes makes the game unique and worth playing. How you carry dialogues with your crew - generals, ambassadors, your queen - and what political decisions you make (to set up public healthcare or even... ban violent books and games) changes your relations with 5 races of Rivellon and situation on Risk map. This, along with troops you bring, decide how the situation will handle in RTS battles you gonna take (if you have low popularity with race living in land you invade or defend, you might not get enough conscripts to defeat enemy - opposite situation is possible as well). This include one-use cards you might gather during gameplay and which alter battles in various ways - by giving you new skills, additional troops or buffing/debuffing various types of units.Main campaign might be short, consider how good you are at such games - but there are always custom ones available.

												This game is absolutely wonderful. It's strongest points are by far story, music, character, political simulation, and turn based strategy. The real time strategy element of it can be...quite vexing and overwhelming at times. The A.I. seems almost relentless, and can easily overwhelm you, not to mention employ a multitude of battlefield control spells that certain units employ quite easier than a human player (unless you're just a pro at the whole RTS scene). If you don't care for the RTS aspect, or the third person dragon action combat on the RTS plain, you can always choose to auto-resolve, relying heavily on your turn based map tactics to win the day. All in all though, this game is 10/10. Loads of different political choices to make as they come before you, things to research, etc. I love this game so much!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												The game really suprised me, it's was unexpectedly fun. Turnbased strategy map + RTS combo, with lots of political intruiges inbetween the turns. It's the political parts that make the game!The core mechanics is that of a turn based strategy game similar to boardgames, and the combat is done RTS style. For people familiar with Total War, this is not something new at all.The difference between this game and total war is a few very meaningful things. First of all, you can only personally partake in ONE combat per turn, which REALLY speeds the game up, and doesn't make you as tired of the RTS moments of the game, which often happens in Total War, when you have HUGE armies all over the map and have to do 20 combats per turn. Controlling the combat becomes a strategical advantage, and you need to utilize this for the right combat per turn, and you can't attack as much. It works great as a game mechanic in this type of games. Makes the game LOT less tedious.Secondly in the combats you take part in, you can turn into a flying dragon that gives you a massive advantage over the enemy. While being a dragon you are in third person and controlling armies become very awkward. It's a decently interesting mechanic, but execution of it is not perfect. It's a bit similar to Sacrifice in this, but not nearly as well polished.The RTS combat is the type with base building. You start with the units you get from strategy map, and you make a base and can only build on certain points of the map, and it's important you take control of the map. It works OK, but becomes very macro focused game play. And if you are outnumbered from units you start with on strategical map, the enemy just rushes you over and you lose, and during first 2 minutes you can use the dragon. It's decently balanced in that. The game have a type of resource used to build units, and it's finite, so eventually you will just have the units you have. If you control more nodes than opponent, you will steal resources from him once the shared finite resource is depleted, so the game is focused on map control mainly.The downside of the RTS combat is the controls, it's VERY clumsy, and there is just too much to do. It's very similar to Starcraft 1, which was a great game of its time, but that was 20 years ago. There is just so many things you can and want to do, but unless you are really really nimble with your fingers and heavily utilize control-groups you will struggle to control your units. Most units also have spells to cast, and none of them are on auto-cast, and combined with the macro-focused game play, and the game becomes very APM-centric. And to top it off it all get even worse in dragon form where you have more limited control. If anything I wish the game had slightly better UI, easier to control combat, it would be much more enjoyable then.This is just the core mechanics of the game, and it's not what makes the game good. That part of the game is just OK, it works somewhat, but is not outstanding or special. What makes this game special is the political intruige between the turns. You as an emperor have to decide on policies for the world, and it's thinly veiled parallells to our world, with common political topics being brought up, like feminism, legalization of weed, religious issues, environmental etc. The different races have different political standings, and overall this is what makes the game great. It's a very smart game, and it will give you pros and cons of all the decisions you make. I've not seen a game like it. It's seriously awesome.Overall this is a Total War game done right, with heavily spiced up flavouring between the turns. If you like the genre you will LOVE this game.

The RTS graphic are near prehistoric and belong on the PS1. If the game was only composed of the things inside the ship I would have been much happier, the voice acting and charater design were top notch. However as it stands it's a primitive, below average RTS wrapped in pretty RPG robes. I disinstalled after 2 hours of gameplay, life is too short.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Unusual mix of RPG (dialogues, decisions and personal stories of your crew aboard your ship, The Raven), TBS (Risk-like map, along with simplified building and research system, armies moving and such), RTS (real-time battles for provinces your invade in previous phase) and action game (when you turn into dragon during RTS battle).Each part is rather simplified and unable to carry the game on its own - yet it is combination of all those modes makes the game unique and worth playing. How you carry dialogues with your crew - generals, ambassadors, your queen - and what political decisions you make (to set up public healthcare or even... ban violent books and games) changes your relations with 5 races of Rivellon and situation on Risk map. This, along with troops you bring, decide how the situation will handle in RTS battles you gonna take (if you have low popularity with race living in land you invade or defend, you might not get enough conscripts to defeat enemy - opposite situation is possible as well). This include one-use cards you might gather during gameplay and which alter battles in various ways - by giving you new skills, additional troops or buffing/debuffing various types of units.Main campaign might be short, consider how good you are at such games - but there are always custom ones available.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												This is a game literally everyone needs to play. Unless you don't like fun. You do like fun, don't you?The game itself is an odd blend of politics, Risk, and a classic RTS game. You play each turn by first exploring your ship, settling political issues that crop up, upgrading your units and/or dragon, as well as talking with your queen when she has the time. The characters you have to interact with are all quite unique and interesting. While they're not exactly complex beings (most of them have a few core personality traits they stick to relentlessly), your own choices in the politics and personal situations you are called to decide upon can have a marked effect on their personality by the end of the game. (I'm looking at you Edmund!!)The next parts of a turn is where Risk comes into play. You build units and move them between the various territories inked out on, quite frankly, lovely maps. There's not a ton to say about this portion of the game. It's very fluid and the game makes sure you don't spend a ton of time here. A few of my peeves actually come from this section of the game. The camera jerks you around between areas when showing your opponent's moves and zooms in inapproriately, keeping you from seeing everything that is happening. Thankfully, you'll have plenty of time to review the board on your next turn, but it's still jarring. Finally, you get to the RTS section of a turn. This can be a ton of fun as this is where you'll have the chance to direct the units you brought into the map, build even more units using a pool of resources everyone must fight over, and most importantly of all, turn into a freaking dragon. Unless it's before the first few minutes have elapsed, or you don't have a certain amount of resources. Okay, so the dragon aspect of the game that gets pushed so hard isn't invulnerable or all-mighty, but honestly I liked that. You have to work with both troops and your dragon, especially as the difficulty cranks up. Everything meshes together to become a lot of fun to play with an excellent replay value to boot. Even the single player campaign can be replayed several times before you see everything. Those political and personal matters that I mentioned you having to deal with are randomized. Even making difference choices on the same decisions can dramatically change your tactics. Okay, TLDR bullet point time.Overall score: 8/10Pros: - Awesome political system that directly imacts your overall strategy. - Colorful and fun characters to interact with.  - Game AI unafraid to teach you a lesson if you get arrogant. - Enough variety of units to allow you to decide your own tactics.  - Completely replayable, even the single player campaign. - Hot keys allow you to continue controlling and building your army even in Dragon Mode. - Simply inspired Voice Acting for each and every character.Cons:  - Naval units as a whole are a bit of an afterthought. - You can certainly feel that a few features were cut from the game. (Looking at you Imp Princess and Orc Race!) - Surprisingly short single player campaign.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												This game is huge and impressive, the gamelplay is quite satisfying and the characters are entertaining for a while. And that's the problem : sometimes, there is nothing to do except moving troops and sometimes, the political themes get predictable and repetitive. Basically, it's fantasy, but without the magic. Not lore-wise, for sure, but metaphorically, there is no sense of wonder whatsoever. I don't know whether this impression of dryness applies to Dragon Commander alone of it is a contant thing in the Divinity saga, but even if this fantasy universe is just immersive enough to justify the price, I felt no ounce of creativity, of originality, there was nothing fresh or wonderful about it. It doesn't means that there is nothing interesting. The story can be fun, somewhat immersive, long enough, and you get to see the main characters' opinions and personalities evolve through time. But if you except interesting things to happen regarding your advisers and diplomats arguments, you'd be completely disappointed. Also, although I can assure you that this point didn't influence my review, some of you might want to know that we get to play a male character in this game, and even if you don't see it and can grow to forget it about time, the marriage "duty" and restrictions with abruptly recall you to this reality. In summary, I'd recommend it for the combat mode, the gameplay, the animation, the aesthetics, but not for the rpg elements.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												Bad bad bad bad.There is no strategy in this real time strategy game.  As an RTS, its an unfeasable zerg rush simulator.  If you take the time to build your base, you will lose.  If you focus on capturing the map, you will lose.  The only strategy is to rush your enemy before it gets some semblance of a foothold.On that note, the enemy can trigger all their abilities at once, while yours have to be done manually, invididually.  The enemy can use all of their buildings, command their troops, and use their abilities all at the same time, making things more onesided as time goes on.If you have the bright idea to bring out your dragon, you will quickly be demolished.  You don't do nearly enough damage, and being a dragon in battle is more of a hinderence than a help.  One you can't leave being in dragon form unless you get yourself killed, so you might even get the pleasure of watching your base get destroyed while you struggle to control your units and buildings from above.Apparently the RPG aspect of the game is either great or abysmal depending on who you ask.  The reviews suggest it between a waifu simulator and a radical tumblr propaganda piece, but you have to get past the rest of the game, which frankly, isn't worth the time or effort, to find out.Don't buy it unless its on sale.  A steep sale. Like... christmas 80% off sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												Dragon commander is an excellent game. Where it simplifies it does so in deference to added complexeties in other regions.All troops are the same, all factions are effectively equivalent. Research adds a bit of differential between factions, but that's it.Otherwise there's a nice political subgame with options for making broad imperial decisions the ramifications of which have an effect on gameplay, and intereactions with a characterized crew/cabinet.Much of the game can be played simply auto-resolving battles and your generals come in handy for just that (though their wages are insane). Each turn you can take control of a RTS battle and take to the skies as your dragon. Various upgrades for your dragon can make it a game changing leader, a strike bomber, a support healer, or a mix therein. This game is slick, it's pretty, it's the best execution of this kind of gimmick since Sacrifice. Multiplayer will add a great deal to its replayability if you can get some friends to play with.You're likely to get 15 odd very pleasant hours out of this game and then if you're like me you're likely to come back to it to see other princesses etc. (P.S. No gendering options are present. You are male and you are afforded chattel princesses.)Also the music is just great, if a smidge repetetive. I found it good enough to tolerate that repetition readily.8/10

content:

												I got my♥♥♥♥♥♥handed to me in the story... and on my wedding day of all days! So I sold my peoples souls to a demon in echange for 2 iowa-class battleships.... which were promptly obliterated by the horde of imps. Would've sold my wife too but i figured it was way too late I had nothing but my capital and her left so might aswell atleast keep her.This games is awesome though. honestly I am unsure wether it's the RTS-battles or the way the campaign map is handled but something is up here, though iI'm not sure exactly what it is. The political part of the game however is excellent though, the issues that come up are fun, and some really make you question what your position on the issues are if you play with a moral compass as I did the first game.My only complaint in that respect is how it kind of feels rushed, and even detached from the war entirely. Like why am I dealing with a genocide that happened in a town that is not under my control? Why do I have any power ofver the society of the Undead, Imps, or Dwarves when none of their provinces are under my control?I feel the political aspect is not perfect, but for the first game of this kind (Atleast that I've seen) it is wonderfully refreshing.From the little references and jokes yelled by your soldiers during battles, to the dark humor, to the rampant homosexuality, high as a kite elves, sociopathic Imps, encouraged necrOphelia. this game is pretty good and I whole heartedly recommend it. It is worth playing, and I plan on playing it again after a couple days break.On a side-note:I do sense a tad bit of prejudice against the religious side though. while between the five races  their seems to be attempts at both balance and degrees when you go to the religious side... it just seems to only be one degree of religion. I think the Elves are supposed to tbe the moderate-religious, and the Lizards the moderate-athiest (maybe Agnostic?). but the only one who really plays the role well is the Lizards, and the elves seem to just let that role drop off completely. but that's just a personal observation, you may see something different.Either way. 8.5/10 I could not be happier with it. but I would suggest buying it on sale. $40 may be just a little steep for the title, but it may not be for you. I personally think anything below $30 is a "must-git deal" as they say back home.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Overall, it is a fun, if flawed, game. Where the game shines is in its political mechanics. As the dragon commander, you make decisions that shape your empire and the personalities of your generals. Every character is well written and has excellent voice acting. The combat, unfortunately, is a bit half baked. It just isn't all that unique and suffers from some poor design decisions. You can't build a base freely, and micro managing your units is fiddly. I found myself autoresolving most of the battles because I simply got bored with the combat. With all that said, I still recommend the game. The decision making mechanics are fun to role play with and the voice acting is so well done it raises the game above its poor rts components.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												Alright, so the Divinity series (and their creators, Larian) have no idea what the bleeding hell they're doing. The first two Divinity games were D3 clones, then their second game was an over the shoulder action RPG where you were an adventurer/dragon, then this game was a multiplayer/single player RTS game that let you turn your overhead camera into a dragon with a jetpack, THEN they made Original Sin Divinity (or whatever that one is called) and was a co-op tactics game.This game, however, succeeded at being fun, so there's that.In Dragon Commander, you play as the Emperor, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ son of the previous emperor who was just murdered by his four other♥♥♥♥♥♥children, who are now busy trying to murder each other to be the new emperor. You also happen to be a dragon because your mother was a dragon pretending to be a human because magic.The game plays three seperate ways in both game modes: First, you play the Tactics mode, where you look at the countries you control and either create units, buildings, or play strategy cards to improve your chances in victory. Secondly, you can either choose to let your AI generals kill the enemy or deal with it yourself whereupon you're thrown into a rather well made RTS game with the usual unit fights, although victory is assured by either destroying the enemy base or by emptying the resource pool and one team running out of soldiers. Thirdly, while playing the second type, you can turn into a dragon and lay waste to the enemy.Surprisingly being a dragon and a commander at the same time controls rather well. You can control the army by either mouse control or (in dragon mode) a bunch of hotkeys that let you cycle and control/use units fluidly. The dragon itself is both overpowered and easily killed. You can destroy enemy soldiers without much trouble, but anti air units (which are common and well built) will murder you gleefully if you're not paying attention.Research and story are both rather enjoyable. It's almost an M-18 movie with a PG-13 tone, so you get contrasting tones and emotions that give you either a smile or a confused frown. Not much else to say there, really, I mean the story's easily ignorable but there's some fun stuff going on in it regardless.Personally I went for the game because it said "You get to be a ♥♥♥♥ing dragon murdering steam tanks with a jetpack." And that is exactly what happens. If nothing else, it's enjoyably honest.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												The game starts you off with a turn-based war game where you push units around on a board to declare their movements, and buy new units and buildings with your gold. When your units end their turn in the same region as enemy troops, the game switches to a real-time mode where you fly around shooting fireballs while little soldiers run around on the field below you. But for some reason, now you can also build troops and buildings! But instead of using gold, you have a different resource called 'recruits' which you build up by capturing buildings called 'Recruitment Centers'. And it seems like the amount of troops you build during the engagement is much larger than the amounts you started with by pushing pieces around on the board. And now I have to keep popping out of the dragon to create new units and order them to do something useful. Extremely stressful and not interesting. These guys should have kept unit creation only in the turn-based game (so that the units you start a fight with are all you get) and let the player have fun with maybe an extremely simple set of commands to give orders in combat.TL;DR: Blowing things up as a dragon is fun. Being responsible for base construction, resource management, and troop movement at the same time is not.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												This is a solid game. It has a lot of irons in the fire design-wise, but you, the player, are certainly not going to feel overwhelmed. Just sit back and enjoy your visual novel with a side of Axis and Allies and a dash of C&C.The RTS combat is nothing to write home about, but not a dealbreaker either. Unitspam is the name of the game, but except in rare circumstances you either win or lose in 15 minutes, so it's not long enough to be tedious. The interesting part is that you can only fight one RTS battle per turn, and for any other combats you've got to trust your generals/cards/the dice gods. This makes you choose things carefully in the map portion of the game, because there's only one battle per turn where you can come out against formidable odds (remember, the bad men have cards too).What you're really here for though is the little political simulator you've got going on with these cookie-cutter-yet-adorable characters in their steampunk outfits. What other game is going to have an elf and a skeleton man trying to sway you on whether or not gay marriage should be legal, or make you choose whether to send the lizardman with a monocle or the man with the brass robot arm to go peacekeep some cult-infested town?

												This game is the epitome of mixing RPG-style choices with Campaign board strategy AND traditional strategy gameplay. The choices that you make in the RPG sections, the upgrades you go with, the land that you take, everything factors into how the game will play out. Will you be a misogynyst and say that women don't get paid the same as men, thus being richer BUT at the same time losing morale, or have equal pay, increasing morale but lowering your money amount? This game is fun, and the RPG decisions are variations of real world issues that are hot-button topics, watching the scenes play out is fun.The game is a good value at $20.00 as well because it is definitely worth multiple playthroughs, not only for the decisions you have to make, but there are 5 different queens to choose from!Check it out, you wont regret it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Take note - this review is being done from an RTS fan who played it casual just to try it out, and hasn't finished it yet...That being said, don't judge when I say that this game is awesome!Divinity - Dragon Commander is the second sequel to the famous Divine Divinity RPG game from way back in the day.  If there's one thing that Larian studios has shown it's a sort of inconsistency in genre of their games, but not in a bad way; with each follow-up they take advantage of the new wave of technological advancements open to them, and they've done a hell of a good job with this one.  Don't expect a hack and slash RPG like Baldr's Gate or Diablo like the original; this is a Real Time Strategy game...but surprisingly not at its core.For the short version, check below, and beware; the long version may have spoilers:The story takes place in Rivellon like the other games, though whether it takes place before or after the events of the second games is unknown (at least to me).  You play as the illegitimate son of a murdered Emperor and a female dragon, and have been chosen by the king's greatest advisor to be the savior of the empire; an empire otherwise riddled with your own half-crazed siblings all of whom want a piece of your draconic flesh.  You can't do this alone of course; you have generals there to help guide you, and advisors to help you keep the people happy...at the cost of potentially others under your care.  Fear not though, for you even have a wife whose marriage ties can give you great benefits with her chosen race, though even she has drama; after all, the worries of the common folk are nothing compared to the worries of the royals, and as the son-born-out-of-wedlock of a dead emperor, your worries are pretty big indeed.The plus is story and character development; each of them being amazing individuals.  Of course, there is one downside; some of them have drama isssues that you need to take up in order to ensure the safety and well-being of your empire, and the issues, unfortunately, can end in two completely different extremes.  For example, Scarlett is one of your generals; young, springy, and itching to fight, she's well worth having in times of need.  But you get hints that she's a little more than what she seems...and it turns out that she's been hiding a very controversial secret about herself...no spoilers, but you get the idea.  I agreed and disagreed with some of her viewpoints, and feared I could either lose her or risk getting my pants set aflame by some very opinionated advisor nobles for agreeing with her.  In the end though, I found a compromise that I actually liked, and she turned out the better for it.Then there's Catherine...*facepalm* where do I begin with her?  Well, she's feminist; formerly a queen of her own country which was a very strict Amazonian society, where women rule and men serve only to hold up the society and help make babies.  In short, any extremist Feminist's pipe dream...and dear Lord, I wanted to have the option to boot her off of my ship in mid-air.  The trouble was, I agreed with some of her plights; she had issues going on that were important, and I'm the kind of guy who respects women and am totally for equal treatment...now, that wasn't the problem.  The problem was that whenever she approached me regarding this...she did what any feminist does; acts like it's my fault because I have a pair of...well, let's be polite, because I'm male and because she's female.  Automatically an issue I had no clue about was my fault just because I was a man...Word to the wise, unless it is their fault, never approach a stubborn man and tell them something is.  If it were up to me, with the stuff she pulled, I would have had her court martialed, flogged, and stripped of title and rank and forced to work a scullery maid, and that's if she was LUCKY...geez...Anyway, that aside, this is a good game.  I can't wait to finish it, it's going really well thus far.  I definitely recommend giving it a go, full price or otherwise, especially since it's graphically beautiful as well as fun.  Getting to play as a dragon in between commanding armies to fight one another is an amazing breath of fresh air, and one of my favorite parts of this game...So, short version: pros and consPros+ Great Story/Setting+ Great gameplay mechanics+ Awesome graphics+ Great sounds, soundtrack, and voice acting+ Awesome characters+ Never a dull momentCons- Extreme left or right decisions in politics- Puts some modern issues in the extreme a little too up front (e.g. Yorrick's pious religious attitude...we religious folks aren't all like that just so you know)- Some of the interactions between yourself and your queen end a little too quickly...got done with the Dwarf queen before I even finished killing off the first enemy faction, two more to go after that.All in all, I give this an 8.5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												Bought this game on impulse when it was a flash sale, and I'm very glad I did.It's part RTS, part RISK, part empire sim, and it manages to mesh together fairly well. You're a half-dragon, seeking to retake your dead father's kingdom from your siblings from a floating ship known as "The Raven." On board your ship, you'll meet with councilors from each of the five races in the game besides humans (dwarves, elves, lizards, imps, undead) to make political decisions to run your exapnding empire. You'll also be tasked with moving your armies around on a Risk-style map, playing cards earned through gameplay to help your forces and hinder your enemy's. Finally, when armies meet on the map, you'll have to command your forces in battle in simplified RTS combat, with the gimmick of being able to transform into a dragon to turn the tide of battle in your favor. The best part of the game is making political decisions to run your empire, and the consequences those decisions entail. Will you implement national healthcare? Deport foreign criminals simply because they're foreign? These are typically not easy decisions to make, as they all have pros and cons. It does get a bit limited--you can only make "yes" or "no" answers to everything. But it's still a very interesing commentary on modern politics. If you're unable to compromise your own views, for example, to keep the other races satisfied, it'll be more difficult for you to raise forces in regions dominated by that race.The RISK style map is basically what you expect. You maneuover your armies around, taking territories and attempting to outsmart the AI- which, so far for me, hasn't been terribly difficult. You can build one building in each territory, from a selection of around 7 or 8. These range from war factories to recruit units with to Wizard Towers that generate cards to give you an advantage in battle.When you confront another army on the map, you can choose to lead your forces into battle, or one of your generals. The RTS-combat is very simple-- there are only around 4 buildings you can build, and one type of resource- recuits. Your main goal is to capture a Recruit plot outside your starting base. If you do this, you'll quickly be able to outproduce your enemy and it won't be long before you overwhelm them. At first, these battles are fun, but they grow repetitive, and you'll find yourself wishing you could skip them entirely. You can, of course, if you elect to have your generals fight for you, Total War- autoresolve style. Unfortunately, this can lead to lost battles that you would otherwise win. The RTS-part's main gimmick- transforming into a dragon-- is fun at first, and creates an interesting mechanic in RTS battles. You can't quene up units while in dragon form, so if you stay transformed too long, you may find yourself out of allied troops to fight with and the battle may turn against you. At the same time, the dragon is powerful and can turn a losing battle into a winning one. Most times, though, the nature of the RTS battles renders the dragon a utility unit. To win, you'll need to outproduce your enemy, and if you're doing that, the battle will quickly snowball in your favor anyways. Divinity: Dragon Commander is a fantastic game. The RTS portion is unfortunately a little weak and gets in the way of the game's more fun empire managing and political decision making, but I would still highly recommend it to strategy enthusiasts.

												Have you ever mixed  bunch of sodas together in an attempt to make something unique and good tasting? For strategy games thats what Divinty: Dragon Commander is. It's quite ambitious in how it brings together concepts that you've probably seen in other games, separately. It takes some of Risk, some Starcraft 2, some Mass Effect and adds a jetpack wearing dragon to the mix to make a memorable gem that balances out serious and comedic moments as you go from blasting enemies on the battlefield to discussing whether or to legalize a certain plant for medical purposes, this and many other political issues in the game are downright parodies of the issues in present day politics, almost making the game an unintentional period piece of our current day and age. The RTS portion can be a little lackluster, but the ability to jump in in the form of a jetpack wearing dragon to fight alongside our forces to tip the scales makes it cooler, and for those who dont want to deal with that and enjoy the admittedly more fun empire running segments it can be auto resolved in a manner similar to the Total War series, with your chances of victory being boosted by paying your general and your various cards. At the end of the day it is a jack of all trades, master of none but the gestalt ends up being greater than the sum of the parts making th experience memorable and makes you want to play the campaign again and again to see how differently things can go and to interact with the very amusing characters in the empire running segments. For strategy fans its worth a buy, for those new to the genre it would be a good gateway to some of the bigger franchises.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												This game is quite fun and the gameplay is solid; my only complaint is that while incorporating many game styles (RTS, turn based conquest, and choose your own adventure dialog) it feels slightly shallow. The RTS aspect of the game is very fun, and the ability of turning into a dragon to lead your armies gives the battles a lot of playablity allowing you to switch constantly between a traditional RTS style or more or of a MOBA style. The RTS mechanics of the game are pretty simple however compared to something like Starcraft with battle being over control nodes for bases, and around 15 units which both the player and AI use; so I don't expect this is a game you could pour hundreds of hours into the multiplier before getting bored. The turn based part of the game plays very much like a game of risk where conquest can be won though a RTS battle, so again it's simple but still effective. Everything else in the game plays out in dialog on your battleship with your generals, advisers and a princess  and they all have great personalities (you either love them or hate, but you care) so it keeps the dialog interesting and offers a lot of choices to keep multiple play through fresh. I enjoyed the game quite a bit, and while it has some shortcomings I would definitely recommend trying this game out, it is better then the sum of all it's parts.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 18, 2013
												A gift from a friend, this game is a bit of an odd-ball mix of Real-Time Strategy and Turn-Base Strategy. Divinity: Dragon Commander is the story of a fallen kingdom where the children murdered the king to fight for the throne (think of Brutus knifing Caeser during the days of the Roman Empire and you'll get the idea) and you, as one good child who didn't take part in the murder, must now take up arms against your siblings and claim the throne for yourself from their tyrannical grasp. Interesting catch is that you're half-dragon; cue the blood and flames.The game is played out in 3 stages of interaction: political with your generals and the people's council representatives; the world map where like Risk and Civilization you move your armies around and secure territory to gain the advantage; and in a RTS during each battle you choose to directly manage yourself on a country's map, where you recruit your forces, build bases and even involve yourself as a dragon (in third-person view) in the battle blasting away at your enemies or healing your forces.Of these 3 stages of gameplay, the RTS is the weakest (it's no Dawn of War, which is the closest RTS to match its style) where it basically falls down to pure numbers overwhelming the enemy control points. But this stage of gameplay can also be the most exciting when you get yourself involved on the battlefield as the dragon, since you can still build forces and command your troops while in this third-person perspective: being the dragon can literally turn the battle when you've only got the slimmest chance of winning the day. The catch is that you can only command one battle yourself per action turn of the second stage of gameplay: where you are you're committed and your generals have to cover another location (again, where they are committed too for that turn), while your army commanders sort themselves out for everywhere else. This second stage of gameplay on the world map is where most of the game takes place, so you have to watch your forces and resource management keenly, playing "political advantage" game cards when possible that you earn from special buildings you can place in your territory. But just as you can do this, so can your CPU enemies back to you so you have to be ready for that too.The final stage of gamplay deserves a seperate mention as the political game with your generals and the people's council on board your command ship can have the most influence on your success (or lack of it). Treat your generals right and they will gain abilities to match your desired morals that you lead by; treat them poorly and they many mutiny. Likewise handle the people's council with care as their support determines how the people of their nations that you claim as territory will treat you as the game goes on: treat them poorly and they'll rise up against you to help your enemies through sabotage, guerrilla warfare and even subversion of your other territories with the rival races. Through this stage of the gameplay a role-playing element exists where you can enter into a political marriage with princesses of four of the five races to improve with your relations with them, but they have their own political needs too that must be managed. Finally this stage of gameplay also covers upgrades that you can give to your military and to your dragon powers to aid you on the other gameplay stages.Special mention must be given to the voice acting and music: for a small development team, it is excellent and the voice acting really sells the game for the interactions with your generals and the people's council.This is one of the longest game reviews I've done because this is one of the varied games I've yet played that has been released on Steam. My recommendation requires this as it'll either be a game you love or hate: strategy fans will really enjoy this game, role-playing fans may be interested in a new experience that is also a "soft" lead into RTS games, while everyone else may find it a tad dull. Check it out if you're curious, but I've certainly being enjoying it.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												To put it bluntly, the actual RTS gameplay is painfully mediocre. It's pretty neat the first few battles as you command your troops while phasing in and out of Dragon form. However, I find the experience to be rather clunky. I am no RTS aficionado but even to me it was rather simplistic and mostly involved sending your entire army to attack move to the enemy base. Despite this, the game is simply fantastic in literally every other way. I eventually just auto-resolved the rest of my battles which helped me transition to where the game shines, its choices. You feel as if you are a true commander, chatting with your generals and helping them resolve differences in order to fight more effectively. You also have to dance politically. As future emperor you must deal with 5 different races, each with their own unique and potentially problematic ideologies. There is no "right" choice when dealing with these hard matters, it truly is just "your" choice. It was interesting to see how my political decisions affecting the army and my townspeople, giving them various buffs and debuffs as the campaign progressed.The graphics are generally good and the game's length is just average. My first run through took me about eight hours as it became substantially easier to win as the game progresses. However, with the many possible paths you could take, it certainly is worth another run.It is a rather unique game  that's main weakness is just in the RTS gameplay. Nevertheless, for its merits alone it deserves a place in my Hall of Fame

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Divinity: Dragon Commander is, in the only possible way to say it, a satirical real-time strategy game with smaller role-playing elements. The game starts strong with teaching you the very basics of the game in a controlled, easy enviroment, before tossing you over the rails into a sea of the craziest happenings. The major aspect of the game is played in a style akin to Risk, with large pools of troops being moved around a world map to capture zones and ultimately the goal of taking control over the whole globe. When two armies clash in a single zone, that's when you get to actually play the RTS aspect. Warning though, the type of RTS that comes with D:DC is displaced by the fact you control yourself as a DRAGON. Yep, you heard me.While the above goes on, you get to deal with a council of representives of the multiple races in the Divinity world. You'll get polled for all sorts of controversial topics, with its open arguments from the liberal and conservative side of your table. Throw in a political marrige with a wife having her own problems, a wizard who's screwing around inside a demon's mind, and a rather cheery goblin who loves to create weapons of mass distruction for you leaves this game as one that doesn't take itself to seriously. And if doesn't take itself too seriously, why should you? Just keep back, play the game, and enjoy the laughs.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												Divinity: Dragon Commander has the feel of one of those bargain bin games you pick up on a whim for 10 dollars and expect it to entertain you for an afternoon. The more you play, the more you see just the amount of sheer love and hard work that went into this wonderful gem of a game that I would call one of my favorite games of the last few years. Dragons are so satisfying to use (although it can trivialize battles a great deal, but then again you are a dragon with a jetpack.) The unit themselves have their own unique flavors and playstyles that make it easy to overlook how few there actually are. Politics are a great way to break up time amongst the Raven, and your side character array is made up of a merry cast that grow on you as you spend time with them and hear their problems.There are some cons to all these of course, mainly the way the AI handles campaigns and some policies. This game favors blitzing through battles and campaigns. Failure to do so will often lead to the enemy getting too strong that not even your overpowered Dragon can handle them. Campaign wise, if you stamp out the enemy too quickly, they may fall into a rut of not counter attacking back and accepting their fate.  If you take too long, you may find yourself hopelessly outclassed against an overwhelming array of troops at their forces versus your village militia. Politics, while fun, suffer from a YES or NO system that can cause you to end up with neither choices feeling satisfying, while a more grey area could have been more of a benefit.Overall, I give this game a 8.5/10 (in normal, non gaming journalism scoring system). This is indeed a great experience that is extremely lovely and rad, but it has small design choices that bring down the experience ever so slightly. That being said, I am now a major fan of Larian and Divinity due to this game and do not regret the 3 purchases I have made towards this game. Dragon Commander is a diamond that deserves a special spot on the shelves where you can look upon it fondly for the true classic it is.

You can auto resolve any/all battles, but if you can't stand the RTS section but don't want it to be just a numbers game you must pay to use commanders. So hopefully you like having to start new games because they didn't explain what was about to happen. This part needs to get a major update.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Divinity: Dragon Commander is an RTS/RPG hybrid game developed by Larian studios, the fellows who created Divine Divinity and Divinity II: The Dragon Knight Saga before going on to create the well received Divinity: Original Sin.At heart, Dragon Commander is an RTS game - you gather resources, make buildings, build units, and go roll over your enemy's stuff.The game may appear simple, but Larian studios decided to add a lot of risky mechanics to spice up their game. This RTS throws in a twist, one loyal to the game's name: playing as the Dragon Commander, you have the ability to drop onto the battle field personally, flying around the battle field in third person and raining down fire on your opponents. This is possibly one of the only RTS games where you have the ability to summon a super unit you control so directly.The execution of the Dragon Commander mechanic is mixed. It's an unfathomably cool idea, and having access to the dragon makes for a very fun 'super' button to push. On the other hand, actually commanding your army is more difficult in this stage - making army selections can't be done with the mouse anymore and casting unit spells becomes a bit of a headache, never mind selecting buildings and creating units out of them. Another side effect is, since the Dragon is partially controlled by the WASD keys, units will not have spells or fuctions bound to those 4 keys, making it less comfortable for those RTS players who like playing with a 'grid' setup (where abilities are hotkeyed according to where they are on the menu).As a pure RTS, the game is weak. The maps do not have wide varieties of objectives, the units are awkward to control, and the mini-map doesn't do much to help navigate. All units supposedly have strengths over others, but there are some which are clearly universaly better than others. One bonus though: free camera control, including the ability to zoom, turn, and even look upwards, a rarity in RTS games!However, despite the RTS portion of the game being weak, there is an added element which adds depth when playing the story mode: the RPG/political side of the game. Earning favor with races means that any time you hold an RTS battle in a country primarily populated with that race you will have a higher maximum army count, as well as more production from that country when you win. It is very possible that if you fail to ever compromise with a race's demands you will enter fights with a max army size a fraction of your opponent's, upon which your only hope of winning the fight is to rush them. The fact that the roleplay element of the game affects the gameplay element is a very tasteful touch which helps put importance to the political debacles presented.Sure, the politics side of the game is not executed in the best way possible and some of the decisions you are presented are obviously better than others, but it's still interesting. You are often presented with decisions such as whether you want to install a public healthcare system, tax the church system, add regulations to limit freedom of the press, etc. Most of the decisions are very tongue-in-cheek versions of current real life issues, and the choices made affect resources and gameplay. Interestingly enough, most of the more 'good' choices end up making the game harder, so compromising with the councillors you do not like is sometimes a necessity in order to have reasonable approval ratings in regions where fights are likely to occur. There are dozens upon dozens of choices to make, decisions branch out into relevant new choices, the characters have a wide variety of personalities, the voice acting is believable, and there is an enormous amount of dialogue that will simply not be seen in a single playthrough. This is all completely optional: everything can be skipped, clicked through, or ignored to get back to the RTS portion, though I wish more games had these kinds of options.All in all, the game is a bit of a power fantasy - except unlike games which turn you into a super-powered being who can screw the lives of evey person in sight (GTA, AC, TES, etc), you get the added perk of being able to screw with the lives of every person out of sight too, and they can't do a thing about it because you're the Dragon Commander/Emperor with incendiary respiration. However, despite having so many glitches and design flaws, and despite the game's concept precluding it from being taken seriously by RTS enthusiasts, at the end of the day the game is just fun. It does a lot of things that no other game of its kind has tried, and though it has not done it in the best way possible, it's the kind of game that makes one hope for a more polished and refined second attempt. As a serious game it has failed, but as a fun romp it has succeeded.I mean come on, Dragon on the battle field. For all the game's flaws, it's hard to say no to that.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												Divinity: Dragon Commander is a great game. I absolutley loved each moment I had with the game. Even when I was being beaten back harshly by the AI on my attempt to start the game on the hardest difficulty, it brought a smile to my face to know that a game is attempting to be challenging nowadays. Thus, please note: This game is hard at the beginning. You start off with two territories, a few armies, and face an enemy that has much more resouces and territory than you do. All the while, you have to juggle the political field with counselors that present problems, choose a wife, and manage your generals. There's also a neat bit where you have to balance gaining resources with losing most of your population. There are three main aspects to the game: Risk, RTS, and Diplomacy.RiskThis game does a fantastic turn-based war map, on par with the old-fashioned Risk board game. It's literally presented as a board game, as you move unit pieces around a map on the bridge of your ship. Everything seems balanced here, as different units constitute different percentages of winning. Assigning generals to the battle will help the battle's odds, but the true varying factor is, indeed, you.RTSYes, you can personally oversee each battle on your own. In the battle, you switch back and forth from commanding your armies to turning into a dragon and fighting them yourself. A timer begins each map (which is rather annoying), in which you must build up the largest force possible to counter the enemy until you can intervene and help your troops on the ground. The RTS feels SOOOO much like Starcraft 2, and fans will probably like it as much as I did. I did not feel that the dragon controls were awkard, and easily commanded my armies as a dragon. Of course, once the battle is done, you must return to the ships, where you are expected to be a diplomat.DiplomacyAfter each battle, matters arise on your ship. Whether one of your generals is fighting for feminism, gay rights, or censorship, you must attend and solve the situation. After that, counselors from Elves, Imps, Undead, Dwarves, and Lizards will constantly fight over issues such as weapon restrictions, violent media, and religious worship. After that, YOU GET TO CHOOSE A WIFE. EACH ONE IS INTERESTING! JUST DON'T CHOOSE THE LIZARD WIFE! Each wife brings forth unique quests and storylines, which further enhance the depth of the universe. One battles with family matters, another with the traditions of her people, and another experiments with ethics and medicine. It's all very interesting and a joy.ConclusionDivinity: Dragon Commander is a great game that has fantastic RTS, Diplomacy, and War-Map gameplay. The only complaint that I have about it is how unequal the counselors are. Every choice seems to be everyone vs. the undead and dwarves. Therefore, if you are conservitave, this game will villify you on 3/5 races. This game actually seems like a great advertisment for liberal beliefs. However, I still loved it, and didn't take it too seriously. 9/10

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Do you enjoy Risk? That would be the question I’d ask, for those inquiring about this game.The nitty gritty of Dragon Commander, is that it’s a videogame implementation of a risk-type strategy boardgame, in a paperback fantasy setting, with solid characters and dialog, and an optional RTS mode. Whew, that sure was a sentence.While the overarching story is something you’d find in a Dragon Lance novel, your generals and councilors will be engaged in CYOA-style stories that develop the land of Rivellon, and your role within it. There’s incredible polish in everything from voice acting, animation, and visual design. As it’s not “Fire Emblem” long, nor “Fire Emblem” hard, I found myself stalling my forces, just so I could engage in more political decisions / view more character moments. So, I mentioned an RTS mode, earlier. Outside of deploying units on the map and essentially rolling the dice- risk-style, you can personally lead one battle, per turn, as a dragon. It plays as a fairly difficult RTS. I didn’t have fun with it, but I tend to be quite poor at RTS’s. It’s thankfully completely optional in beating the game, and probably best used as a way to change an unlikely battle’s odds. I kept wishing I could pause and direct orders.I will say that it’s RTS implementation is pretty novel. It’s kinda like Brutal Legend, in of that you can engage the world directly as a unit, in the midst of managing soldiers. All in all, I would definitely recommend Divinity: Dragon Commander for a long weekend.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2013
												What a strange game. It's a mishmash of Civilization, of Starcraft, of Brutal Legend, of half a dozen other things, all stripped down and neatly tied together with some excellent voice acting and beautiful visuals. No single element would hold up under heavy scrutiny, but the volume of options, modes, mechanics and meaningful choices add up to a fun time. If you think Civ was too involved or moved too slowly, if you thought Starcraft was too complicated and relied too much on twitch, if you thought Brutal Legend was a cool game but didn't like the aesthetic, and if you ever wanted to strap a jetpack to a dragon and decide whether to implement national healthcare in the same game, then it's probably the game for you, even if it might wear thin eventually from lack of depth. Even so, there's always the chance the developers will add on more content to it, like maybe some more tutorial information (not that it's too hard to figure out.) 4/5 for now, I'll update when I have some more experience.

												While the RTS elements seem fairly good (if not as good as something like Starcraft or Warcraft), where the game shines is in the campaign. The risk style planning, politics, and story are all excellent, and easily blow Starcraft 2's between-mission-hub out of the water.
